items.question: Which of the following is a common characteristic of steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: They use slope and gravity as the primary method to keep water out.
They rely on a weatherproof membrane as the main barrier.
They are typically installed on slopes of 3:12 or less.
They are always constructed using a single continuous sheet.

items.explanation: Steep-slope roof systems are generally water-shedding, using slope and gravity as the primary method to keep water out of the building, as described in the excerpt.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT typically considered a steep-slope roof system?

options.text: Asphalt shingle system
Metal roof system
Built-up roof (BUR) system
Slate system

items.explanation: Built-up roof (BUR) systems are listed as a common low-slope roof system, not a steep-slope system, in the provided material.

items.question: According to the NCCER Roofing program, which roof slope is classified as steep-slope?

options.text: C. Above 3:12
D. 3:12 or less

items.explanation: The excerpt states that the NCCER Roofing program defines steep-slope roofs as those with a slope above 3:12.

items.question: What is the primary function of a steep-slope roof system?

options.text: A. To retain water for insulation
B. To shed water using gravity
C. To provide a hydrostatic barrier
D. To support heavy rooftop equipment

items.explanation: The excerpt explains that steep-slope roof systems are designed to shed water, relying on gravity to move water off the roof.

items.question: According to NRCA guidelines, what is the minimum recommended slope for applying asphalt shingles with a single layer of No. 15 asphalt-saturated felt underlayment?

options.text: A. 2 inches per foot (17%)
B. 3 inches per foot (25%)
C. 4 inches per foot (33%)
D. 6 inches per foot (50%)

items.explanation: NRCA specifies that asphalt shingles may be applied on roof decks with a slope of 4 inches per foot (33%) or more, provided a minimum of one layer of No. 15 asphalt-saturated felt is used as underlayment.

items.question: What is the primary purpose of installing a starter course of asphalt shingles or mineral-surfaced roll roofing along the downslope edge of a steep-slope roof?

options.text: A. To provide additional insulation
B. To improve the aesthetic appearance
C. To shed water that migrates through joints and cut-outs of the overlying first course
D. To anchor the underlayment to the deck

items.explanation: The starter course is applied to shed water that may pass through the joints and cut-outs of the first course of shingles, protecting the underlying construction from moisture intrusion.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT a typical step in the leak investigation process for steep-slope roof repair?

options.text: A. Asking questions about the leak and building.
B. Photographing the roof after repairs have been made.
C. Assessing the inside of the building.
D. Seeking potential causes of the leak with a process of elimination.

items.explanation: Photographing the roof after repairs have been made is not part of the leak investigation process, which focuses on diagnosing the problem before any repairs are performed.

items.question: When repairing underlayment in a steep-slope roof system, what is the recommended first step?

options.text: A. Replace damaged underlayment without removing roof covering.
B. Remove the shingles, tiles, or panels to expose the underlayment.
C. Patch the underlayment from underneath the roof deck.
D. Apply sealant directly to the roof covering.

items.explanation: The excerpt states that to repair underlayment, you must remove the shingles, tiles, or panels to expose it before replacing damaged sections.

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual: Steep-slope Roof Systems—2013, which roof deck substrate does NRCA recommend for the direct attachment of asphalt shingle roof systems?

options.text: A. Gypsum panels
B. Wood panels, wood planks, or wood boards
C. Concrete planks
D. Cementitious wood fiber panels

items.explanation: NRCA recommends asphalt shingle roof systems be directly attached only to structural wood panel decks, wood planks, or wood boards, and does not recommend direct attachment to gypsum, concrete, cementitious wood fiber, or similar nonwood materials.

items.question: What is the minimum recommended roof deck slope for the application of asphalt shingle roof systems, as specified by NRCA?
items.explanation: NRCA recommends designers specify roof deck slopes intended for the application of asphalt shingle roof systems at 4:12 or greater.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, what is the preferred type of expansion joint for steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: A. Flat expansion joint in the same plane as the roof covering
B. Raised curb type expansion joint
C. Expansion joint covered only with membrane
D. Prefabricated pipe flashing joint

items.explanation: NRCA considers raised curb type expansion joints to be preferred for steep-slope roof systems, as stated in Appendix 1 of the source.

items.question: When installing snow guards on steep-slope roof systems, which attachment method does NRCA recommend to minimize leakage risk?

options.text: A. Adhered attachment using manufacturer-recommended adhesives
B. Attachment with exposed fasteners
C. Attachment with concealed fasteners under an upper shingle
D. Clamping attachment for all roof types

items.explanation: NRCA recommends snow guards be attached with concealed fasteners to avoid creating potential locations for leakage, rather than using exposed fasteners or adhesives.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, what is the minimum roof slope required for clay and concrete tile roof systems?
items.explanation: The NRCA Roofing Manual specifies that designers should specify roof deck slopes intended for the application of tile roof systems at 4:12 or greater, making 4:12 the minimum recommended slope.

items.question: Which of the following is NOT recommended by NRCA as a substrate for mechanically attached clay and concrete tile roof systems?

options.text: A. Wood panels
B. Wood planks
C. Batten systems
D. Gypsum decks

items.explanation: NRCA does not recommend the direct, mechanical attachment of tile to gypsum, concrete plank, cementitious wood fiber, or similar nonwood materials; instead, a nailable wood substrate should be installed over such decks.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, what is the minimum roof slope for the installation of wood shake and wood shingle roof systems?
items.explanation: NRCA recommends designers specify substrates for wood shake and wood shingle roof systems have slopes of 4:12 or more, ensuring effective water shedding and system performance.

items.question: When installing wood shakes or wood shingles over spaced (skipped) sheathing, what does NRCA recommend regarding the use of underlayment?

options.text: A. Always use a single layer of underlayment
B. Omit underlayment to promote venting and drying
C. Use double layers of underlayment
D. Only use underlayment in high-wind areas

items.explanation: NRCA does not recommend the use of underlayment when wood shakes or wood shingles are installed over spaced sheathing, as omitting it promotes venting and drying of the wood.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, what is the minimum height above the finished roof surface for expansion joint details in steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: A. 4 inches
B. 6 inches
C. 8 inches
D. 10 inches

items.explanation: NRCA recommends that expansion joints in steep-slope roof systems be detailed and constructed to a height of 8 inches above the finished roof surface to ensure proper performance and weathertightness.

items.question: What type of fastener attachment does NRCA recommend for snow guards on steep-slope roof systems to minimize leakage risk?

options.text: A. Exposed fasteners
B. Concealed fasteners
C. Adhered attachment
D. Welded attachment

items.explanation: NRCA recommends attachment of snow guards with concealed fasteners to avoid penetrating the steep-slope roof covering and creating potential locations for leakage.

items.question: Which of the following best describes a steep-slope roof according to the provided definitions?

options.text: A roof with a slope less than 3:12, designed to resist water pressure.
A roof with a slope greater than 3:12, designed to shed water rapidly.
A roof with a slope exactly 3:12, designed for waterproofing.
A roof with no slope, designed for maximum insulation.

items.explanation: The excerpt defines steep-slope roofing as a category of roofing installed on slopes exceeding 3:12 (or 25 percent), designed to shed water rapidly rather than resist water pressure.

items.question: What is the primary function of stepped flashing on a steep-slope roof?

options.text: To provide insulation at the roof perimeter.
To overlap and step up the vertical surface around projections such as chimneys and dormers.
To secure the roof membrane to the deck.
To create a watertight seal at the roof ridge.

items.explanation: Stepped flashing consists of individual pieces of material overlapped and stepped up the vertical surface to flash around projections like chimneys and dormers on steep-slope roofs.

items.question: What is the primary purpose of the starter course in the installation of three-tab asphalt shingles on a steep-slope roof?

options.text: A. To provide additional insulation at the eave
B. To bond with the overlying shingles for improved wind performance
C. To prevent ice dam formation
D. To increase the aesthetic appeal of the roof

items.explanation: The starter course consists of three-tab shingles with tabs cut off and is installed so that its self-sealing adhesive line bonds with the overlying shingles, providing better wind performance to the roof.

items.question: Which type of valley treatment in asphalt shingle roofs is generally more durable and better able to withstand roofers' foot traffic?

options.text: A. Open valley with sheet metal flashing
B. Closed-cut valley
C. Woven valley
D. Open valley with roll roofing material

items.explanation: A woven valley weaves shingles from adjacent roofs together, resulting in greater thickness of roofing material and increased durability, especially against foot traffic in the valley area.

items.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding the installation of slate roofs on steep slopes?

options.text: A. Slate roofs require no underlayment regardless of slope.
B. For slopes greater than 20:12, a minimum of one No. 30 asphalt-saturated felt underlayment is required for standard slate roofs.
C. Slate roofs should always use two layers of No. 45 felt, regardless of slope.
D. Headlap requirements are not affected by roof slope.

items.explanation: The excerpt specifies that for roof slopes greater than 20:12, a minimum of one No. 30 asphalt-saturated felt underlayment is required for standard slate roofs. Underlayment and headlap requirements do vary with slope.

items.question: What is the recommended method for securing slates on a standard steep-slope slate roof?

options.text: A. Only adhesive should be used.
B. Slates should be nailed through pre-punched holes, ideally with copper slating nails.
C. Slates should be glued directly to the underlayment.
D. Slates should be stapled with galvanized staples.

items.explanation: The source states that slates are secured to the deck with nails driven through pre-punched holes, and copper slating nails are generally recommended for their ease of removal during repairs.

items.question: Which of the following statements about architectural sheet metal roofs is correct?

options.text: A. They do not require a supporting deck or underlayment.
B. They are intended for use on low-slope roofs only.
C. They require a supporting deck and underlayment and are meant for steep slopes.
D. They are always custom-made and never manufacturer-specific.

items.explanation: Architectural sheet metal roofs require a supporting deck and underlayment and are designed for steep slopes (slope ≥ 3:12), as stated in the excerpt.

items.question: What is the primary reason for using an ice dam protection membrane on architectural metal roofs in areas with high snow loads?

options.text: A. To improve the aesthetic appearance of the roof
B. To prevent adhesion between metal panels and underlayment
C. To provide secondary waterproofing against leaks caused by ice dams
D. To increase the thermal insulation of the roof assembly

items.explanation: The excerpt specifies that an ice dam protection membrane should be installed over the entire roof in areas with high snow loads to provide secondary waterproofing and prevent leaks caused by ice dams.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, what is the minimum upslope extension for a water and ice-dam protection membrane from the inside of the exterior wall line on steep-slope roofs with slopes less than 4:12?

options.text: A. 12 inches
B. 24 inches
C. 36 inches
D. 48 inches

items.explanation: The NRCA recommends that for slopes less than 4:12, water and ice-dam protection membrane should extend upslope a minimum of 36 inches from inside the exterior wall line.

items.question: When installing asphalt shingles on steep-slope roof systems, what is the recommended minimum penetration of fasteners into roof decks greater than 3/4 inch thick?

options.text: A. 1/8 inch
B. 1/2 inch
C. 3/4 inch
D. 1 inch

items.explanation: Fasteners should penetrate at least 3/4 inch into roof decks greater than 3/4 inch thick to ensure secure attachment of asphalt shingles.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, for slopes less than 4:12, what is the minimum upslope extension required for water and ice-dam protection membrane from the inside of the exterior wall line?

options.text: A. 12 inches
B. 24 inches
C. 36 inches
D. 48 inches

items.explanation: The excerpt states that for slopes less than 4:12, NRCA recommends a minimum of 36 inches upslope extension for water and ice-dam protection membrane from the inside of the exterior wall line.

items.question: What is the recommended method for securing tile in an open valley detail according to the NRCA Roofing Manual: Steep-slope Roof Systems—2009?

options.text: A. Fasten tiles directly through the valley metal
B. Use wire-tied systems to secure tiles
C. Use adhesive under the tiles
D. Overlap tiles without any fasteners

items.explanation: The source specifies that tiles should not be fastened through the valley metal and instead recommends using wire-tied systems for securing tiles in open valley details.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, for slopes less than 4:12, what is the minimum upslope extension required for water and ice-dam protection membrane from the inside of the exterior wall line?

options.text: A. 12 inches
B. 24 inches
C. 36 inches
D. 48 inches

items.explanation: The NRCA recommends that for slopes less than 4:12, water and ice-dam protection membrane should extend upslope a minimum of 36 inches from the inside of the exterior wall line.

items.question: What is the recommended spacing for fasteners used to secure metal eave riser/closure strips in clay and concrete tile roof systems?

options.text: A. 6 inches on center
B. 12 inches on center
C. 18 inches on center
D. 24 inches on center

items.explanation: The construction details specify that fasteners for metal eave riser/closure strips should be installed approximately 12 inches on center.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, what is the minimum upslope extension for water and ice-dam protection membrane from the inside of the exterior wall line on steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: A. 12 inches
B. 24 inches
C. 36 inches
D. 48 inches

items.explanation: The NRCA Roofing Manual specifies that water and ice-dam protection membrane should extend upslope a minimum of 24 inches from inside the exterior wall line, and for slopes less than 4:12, a minimum of 36 inches is recommended.

items.question: When installing snow guards on steep-slope roof systems, what does NRCA recommend to prevent leakage associated with exposed fasteners?

options.text: A. Use exposed fasteners for easier installation
B. Penetrate the roof covering with fasteners
C. Avoid penetrating the roof covering with exposed fasteners
D. Install snow guards only at the eave

items.explanation: NRCA recommends that the steep-slope roof covering not be penetrated by exposed fasteners when installing snow guards, to avoid potential leakage related to snow guard installation.

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual, for slopes less than 4:12, what is the recommended minimum upslope extension of water and ice-dam protection membrane from inside the exterior wall line?

options.text: A. 12 inches
B. 24 inches
C. 36 inches
D. 48 inches

items.explanation: The source states that for slopes less than 4:12, NRCA recommends a minimum of 36 inches upslope extension for water and ice-dam protection membrane from inside the exterior wall line.

items.question: Which component is described as optional in certain applications at the eave of wood shake and wood shingle steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: A. Water and ice-dam protection membrane
B. Drip edge metal
C. Starter course
D. Fasteners

items.explanation: The excerpt notes that in certain applications, drip edge metal may not be required at the eave, making it optional.

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual, what is the recommended minimum upslope extension for water and ice-dam protection membrane from the inside of the exterior wall line for slopes less than 4:12?

options.text: A. 12 inches
B. 24 inches
C. 36 inches
D. 48 inches

items.explanation: The source states that for slopes less than 4:12, NRCA recommends a minimum of 36 inches upslope extension for water and ice-dam protection membrane from the inside of the exterior wall line.

items.question: When installing wood shingles in an open valley detail, which of the following is NOT recommended according to the NRCA Roofing Manual?

options.text: A. Extending wood shingles a minimum of 4 inches over valley metal
B. Lapping valley metal a minimum of 8 inches and setting in sealant
C. Fastening shingles through the metal valley
D. Using valley underlayment appropriate for climatic conditions

items.explanation: The source explicitly states that shingles should not be fastened through metal valley in open valley details.

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual, which of the following is NOT considered appropriate for re-cover applications?

options.text: A. Clay and concrete tile roof systems
B. Asphalt shingle roof systems
C. Metal panel roof systems
D. Slate roof systems

items.explanation: The excerpt states that NRCA does not consider clay and concrete tile roof systems appropriate for re-cover applications, while no such restriction is mentioned for the other listed systems.

items.question: What is the recommended minimum clearance between a pipe penetration and a valley center in clay and concrete tile roof systems?

options.text: A. 6 inches
B. 12 inches
C. 18 inches
D. 24 inches

items.explanation: The excerpt specifies that NRCA recommends a minimum distance of 18 inches between a penetration and valley center to facilitate proper installation of flashings.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations for metal shingle roof systems, what is the minimum slope that should be specified for the substrate?
items.explanation: NRCA recommends designers specify substrates for metal shingle roof systems have slopes of 4:12 or more to ensure effective water shedding and system performance.

items.question: When constructing an open valley for a metal shingle roof system, how far should fasteners generally be kept back from the center of the valley?

options.text: A. 2 inches
B. 4 inches
C. 8 inches
D. 12 inches

items.explanation: Fasteners should generally be kept back from the center of a valley a minimum of 8 inches to prevent leakage, as recommended by NRCA.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, when should cricket flashing be installed on the upslope side of a skylight in steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: A. When the skylight is less than 12 inches wide
B. Only when the roof slope is less than 4:12
C. When the skylight is more than 24 inches wide and curb height permits
D. Whenever a skylight is present, regardless of size

items.explanation: The excerpt states that NRCA suggests cricket flashing on the upslope side of skylights when they are more than 24 inches wide, provided curb height permits.

items.question: What is the recommended minimum height for base flashing at premanufactured expansion joint covers on steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: A. 4 inches above the finished roof surface
B. 6 inches above the finished roof surface
C. 8 inches above the finished roof surface
D. 12 inches above the finished roof surface

items.explanation: The source specifies that NRCA recommends a minimum base flashing height of 8 inches above the finished roof surface for premanufactured expansion joint covers.

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual: Steep-slope Roof Systems—2017, what is the minimum recommended roof deck slope for the application of asphalt shingle roof systems?
items.explanation: The manual specifies that designers should specify roof deck slopes intended for the application of asphalt shingle roof systems at 4:12 or greater (p. 43).

items.question: Which roof deck substrate does NRCA recommend for the direct attachment of asphalt shingle roof systems?

options.text: A. Gypsum panels
B. Structural wood panels, wood planks, or wood boards
C. Concrete planks
D. Cementitious wood fiber panels

items.explanation: NRCA recommends asphalt shingle roof systems be directly attached only to structural wood panel decks, wood plank or wood board decks, and does not recommend direct attachment to non-wood or fabricated wood materials (p. 43, 47).

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual, which type of flashing is recommended for chimneys wider than 24 inches on steep-slope clay and concrete tile roof systems?

options.text: A. Apron flashing
B. Backer flashing
C. Cricket flashing
D. Channel flashing only

items.explanation: The manual specifies that cricket flashing is used at masonry chimneys wider than 24 inches to divert water and improve drainage on steep-slope clay and concrete tile roof systems.

items.question: When transitioning from a steep-slope to a low-slope roof system with tile, which compatibility consideration is specifically noted in the NRCA Roofing Manual?

options.text: A. Compatibility of tile and wood battens
B. Compatibility of underlayment and low-slope membrane
C. Compatibility of flashing and drip edge
D. Compatibility of tile and insulation

items.explanation: The manual notes that compatibility of underlayment and low-slope membrane should be considered at steep- to low-slope roof system transitions to ensure proper performance.

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual, what is the recommended minimum overhang for wood shakes or shingles with L-type drip edge metal at the eave?

options.text: A. 1/4 inch
B. 1/2 inch
C. 1 to 1 1/2 inches
D. 2 inches

items.explanation: The excerpt repeatedly specifies an overhang of approximately 1/2 inch to 1 1/2 inches with L-type drip edge metal at the eave for wood shakes and shingles, making option C correct.

items.question: When installing wood shakes at an open valley, what is a key requirement regarding fasteners?

options.text: A. Fasten shakes directly through the metal valley
B. Use only one fastener per shake
C. Shakes should not be fastened through metal valley
D. Fasteners must be visible after installation

items.explanation: The source clearly states that shakes should not be fastened through the metal valley, ensuring the integrity of the valley flashing and preventing leaks.

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual, what is the recommended minimum height for expansion joints above the finished roof surface in steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: A. 4 inches
B. 6 inches
C. 8 inches
D. 12 inches

items.explanation: The manual states that for most steep-slope roof systems, expansion joints should be detailed and constructed to a height of 8 inches above the finished roof surface.

items.question: What type of expansion joint does NRCA recommend for steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: A. Flat expansion joint in the same plane as the roof covering
B. Raised curb type expansion joint
C. Prefabricated pipe expansion joint
D. Flexible membrane expansion joint

items.explanation: NRCA recommends raised curb type expansion joints for steep-slope roof systems, as opposed to joints in the same plane as the roof covering.

items.question: According to the General Pitched Roof Specification Guide, what is the minimum number of roofing nails required per shingle in high wind areas and the coastline?
items.explanation: The specification states that a minimum of 4 nails per shingle is required, but in high wind areas and the coastline, 6 nails per shingle are mandated.

items.question: What is the minimum thickness required for self-adhering sheet underlayment used on pitched roofs according to the specification guide?

options.text: A. 20-mil
B. 30-mil
C. 40-mil
D. 50-mil

items.explanation: The guide specifies that self-adhering sheet underlayment must be a minimum of 40-mil thick, as per ASTM 1970.

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual: Steep-slope Roof Systems—2021, what is the recommended minimum roof slope for the application of asphalt shingle roof systems?
items.explanation: NRCA recommends designers specify roof deck slopes intended for the application of asphalt shingle roof systems at 4:12 or greater, as stated in Chapter 2—Roof Decks.

items.question: Which of the following roof deck substrates does NRCA recommend for the direct attachment of asphalt shingle roof systems?

options.text: A. Gypsum panels
B. Wood panels or wood boards
C. Concrete planks
D. Cementitious wood fiber panels

items.explanation: NRCA recommends asphalt shingle roof systems be directly attached only to structural wood panel decks, wood plank or wood board decks, and does not recommend direct attachment to non-wood substrates.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, what is the minimum roof slope for new construction or roof replacement when installing a slate roof system?
items.explanation: The NRCA Roofing Manual specifies a minimum recommended slope of 4:12 for new construction and roof replacement projects involving slate roof systems, aligning with both NRCA and code requirements.

items.question: Which substrate is NOT considered adequate for direct application of slate roof systems according to NRCA recommendations?

options.text: A. Closely spaced wood planks
B. Continuous wood panels
C. Spaced wood plank decks
D. Wood boards

items.explanation: NRCA explicitly states that spaced, or 'skipped,' wood plank or wood board decks are not considered an adequate substrate for slate roof systems; only continuous wood panels or closely spaced wood planks/boards are recommended.

items.question: Which of the following is a significant advantage of synthetic slate roof coverings compared to natural slate for steep-slope applications?

options.text: A. Synthetic slate requires special tools for installation.
B. Synthetic slate weighs about one-third the weight of natural slate.
C. Synthetic slate must be installed with increased structural loading.
D. Synthetic slate is only available in panels.

items.explanation: Synthetic slate weighs about one-third the weight of natural slate, allowing it to be installed over conventional substrates without the need for increased structural loading. (NRCA-5005e-3384_Part6.pdf)

items.question: What is a current limitation regarding the technical evaluation of synthetic steep-slope roof covering materials?

options.text: A. All synthetic roof coverings are tested using a uniform battery of tests.
B. The International Building Code recognizes all synthetic roof coverings.
C. There are no consensus standards for testing synthetic roof coverings.
D. Synthetic roof coverings cannot be manufactured using recycled materials.

items.explanation: There are no consensus standards for the testing of synthetic roof coverings, making technical evaluation and comparison difficult. (NRCA-5005e-3384_Part6.pdf)

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual: Steep-slope Roof Systems—2021, what is the recommended minimum slope for the application of asphalt shingle roof systems?
items.explanation: The manual states that NRCA recommends designers specify roof deck slopes intended for the application of asphalt shingle roof systems at 4:12 or greater, even though codes may allow slopes as low as 2:12.

items.question: Which of the following roof deck substrates is NOT recommended by NRCA for direct attachment of asphalt shingles in steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: A. Wood panels (plywood, OSB)
B. Wood planks and wood boards
C. Gypsum or concrete planks
D. Closely spaced wood boards

items.explanation: NRCA does not recommend the direct attachment of asphalt shingles to gypsum, concrete planks, cementitious wood fiber, or similar non-wood or fabricated wood materials; wood panels and boards are recommended.

items.question: According to NRCA recommendations, what is the minimum roof slope for new construction or roof replacement with wood shake or wood shingle roof systems?
items.explanation: NRCA recommends designers specify roof deck slopes intended for the application of wood shake or wood shingle roof systems at 4:12 or greater, even though codes may allow 3:12.

items.question: When installing wood shakes over spaced sheathing, what does NRCA recommend regarding the use of underlayment?

options.text: A. Use a double layer of underlayment
B. Use a single layer of underlayment
C. Do not use underlayment
D. Use only synthetic underlayment

items.explanation: NRCA does not recommend the use of a separate underlayment in addition to the interlayment when wood shakes are installed over spaced (skipped) sheathing, to promote venting and drying.

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual, what is the recommended minimum overhang of clay or concrete tile beyond the drip edge at the eave for steep-slope roof systems?

options.text: A. 1/4 inch
B. 1/2 inch
C. 2 inches
D. 4 inches

items.explanation: Multiple details in the excerpt (e.g., TILE(PC)-1, TILE(PC)-2, TILE(PC)-3, TILE(S)-1) specify an approximate 1/2" overhang of tile beyond the drip edge at the eave for steep-slope clay and concrete tile roof systems.

items.question: When transitioning from a steep-slope to a low-slope roof system, what is a key consideration for the underlayment and membrane according to the NRCA Roofing Manual?

options.text: A. Use only asphalt-based underlayment
B. Compatibility of underlayment and low-slope membrane should be considered
C. Underlayment must be omitted at the transition
D. Membrane should always be installed over the tile

items.explanation: The notes for steep- to low-slope roof system transitions (TILE(ILB)-17, TILE(PC)-17, TILE(PC)-17A) repeatedly state that compatibility of underlayment and low-slope membrane should be considered at these transitions.

items.question: According to the NRCA Roofing Manual, what is the recommended minimum slope for new construction or roof replacement when installing metal shingle roof systems?
items.explanation: The manual states that while the International Building Code and International Residential Code allow a minimum slope of 2:12, NRCA recommends a minimum slope of 4:12 for new construction or roof replacement with metal shingle roof systems to ensure proper water shedding and system performance.

items.question: When installing metal shingle roof systems over wood panel decks, what minimum nominal thickness does NRCA recommend for plywood panels with 16-inch rafter spacing?

options.text: A. 3/8 inch
B. 1/2 inch (actual 15/32 inch)
C. 5/8 inch (actual 19/32 inch)
D. 3/4 inch

items.explanation: NRCA recommends a minimum of four-ply, nominal thickness of 1/2 inch (actual thickness of 15/32 inch) plywood for 16-inch rafter spacings to provide adequate support and fastener pull-out resistance for metal shingle roof systems.

items.question: According to the NRCA Steep Roofing Manual, what is the minimum recommended slope for applying asphalt roll roofing material using the Exposed Nail Method parallel to the rake?

options.text: A. 1 inch per foot
B. 2 inches per foot
C. 3 inches per foot
D. 4 inches per foot

items.explanation: The manual specifies that asphalt roll roofing materials may be applied parallel to the rake using the Exposed Nail Method only on roof decks having a slope of 4 inches per foot or more.

items.question: When installing asphalt self-sealing strip shingles with tabs on a roof deck with a slope of 3 inches per foot, what is the minimum underlayment requirement according to NRCA guidelines?

options.text: A. One layer of No. 15 asphalt-saturated felt
B. Two layers of No. 15 asphalt-saturated felt

items.question: Why is it important to install Roof Deck Protection under shingles in modern homes?

B. It acts as a temporary waterproof roof.

items.explanation: Roof Deck Protection provides secondary water-shedding protection and helps reduce moisture that can become trapped under shingles, which is especially important in modern, tightly sealed homes.

items.question: What must be considered when using non-breathable Roof Deck Protection under shingles?

items.question: Which of the following statements best describes the difference between sprayed polyurethane foam (SPF) and rigid polyisocyanurate insulation in roofing applications?

options.text: A. SPF is applied as board stock at the job site, while polyisocyanurate is sprayed in place.

C. Both SPF and polyisocyanurate are always installed as factory-formed boards.

items.question: What is the recommended minimum thickness for sprayed polyurethane foam (SPF) when surfaced with an elastomeric coating over rough-textured substrates?

items.question: According to Specification Plate 41-IAOA, which insulation substrate requires a thin layer of wood fiberboard, perlitic board, or glass fiber board insulation to be installed over its top surface before applying the roof membrane?

items.question: What is the preferred method for installing the first ply of the roof membrane over insulation substrates other than composite board, polyurethane foam board, and polyisocyanurate foam board, as described in Specification Plate 41-IAOA?

B. Protect from adverse weather at all times, including transit

items.question: According to the excerpt, what is a recommended method for securing the 4 ft wide strip of insulation around the roof perimeter in Class I steel deck construction?
